critique: This document primarily concerns the administration and organization of the Foreign Service. It establishes a Board of the Foreign Service within the Department of State and outlines its composition, including representatives from various agencies. It also allows the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Commerce to utilize the Foreign Service personnel system for specific positions. There is nothing explicitly ideological in this document. It does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or economic regulation. It seems to consolidate power at the federal level by creating a board, but this is within the executive branch and doesn't necessarily expand executive power beyond its intended scope. It also doesn't seem to promote or hinder social inclusion.
